title: 1957 Masters Tournament
text:
The 1957 Masters Tournament was the 21st <a href="Masters%20Tournament">Masters Tournament</a>, held April 4–7 at <a href="Augusta%20National%20Golf%20Club">Augusta National Golf Club</a> in <a href="Augusta%2C%20Georgia">Augusta, Georgia</a>. This was the first Masters played with a 36-hole cut; 101 players started and forty made the cut at 150 (+6).
<a href="Doug%20Ford%20%28golfer%29">Doug Ford</a> won his only Masters, three strokes ahead of runner-up <a href="Sam%20Snead">Sam Snead</a>, a three-time champion. Snead was the third round leader, but could only shoot even-par in a round that included six birdies and six bogeys. Ford was three strokes back after 54 holes, but was bogey-free on Sunday. On the final hole, Ford holed out from the bunker for birdie for his 66 (–6). This was Ford's second and final <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major</a> title; he also won the <a href="1955%20PGA%20Championship">1955 PGA Championship</a>.
This year was the Masters debut of <a href="Gary%20Player">Gary Player</a>, age 21, and he tied for 24th. He won three Masters, in <a href="1961%20Masters%20Tournament">1961</a>, <a href="1974%20Masters%20Tournament">1974</a>, and <a href="1978%20Masters%20Tournament">1978</a>. Five-time <a href="Open%20Championship">British Open</a> winner <a href="Peter%20Thomson%20%28golfer%29">Peter Thomson</a> was fifth, his best career finish in the Masters. Amateur <a href="Harvie%20Ward">Harvie Ward</a> was fourth at even-par 288, five strokes behind Ford.
Two-time champion <a href="Ben%20Hogan">Ben Hogan</a> had finished in the top ten in the last fourteen Masters that he had entered, but had 32 putts on Friday and missed the event's first-ever cut by a stroke. It was the only cut he missed at Augusta; in nine more Masters he had three top ten finishes, including his final appearance at age 54 in <a href="1967%20Masters%20Tournament">1967</a>.
Field.
This was the last year when professionals were invited based solely on qualification in amateur events.
